div.p:
The proper topics of discussion (discccuion) in the upper (pper)
world was not the Play at the (t e) Bankside but the life of man.
The titles xxxxxxx of the Essays enumerate (enumaerate) the [illeg.] of those topics.
"Of Truth. Of Death. Of Unity in religion. Of Revenge.
Of Simulation and Dissimulation (Dissumlation)." These were the subjects
that the rulers discussed at their high tables;
and the play was a diversion with which to relax the mind
after serious work. The sediment of that conversation is
to be found in the rich deposits of the essays. He is concern
with the great world of action; with government; with the
tortuous matures of Princes; with the arts by which Princes
can sway (way), can coax, can suppress. He lives entirely
in the world of great spirits and great business. The common
people (peopl) is contemptible. The master of superstition is
the (t e) people." Praise, "if it be from the common people,
it is commonly false and naught. The lowest virtues draw
praise from them; the middle virtues work in them astonish

ment; and admiration; but of the highest vertues they have
no sense or perceiving (percebing) at all."

The soul that walked between delicate groves, now
and then formulating a phrase (pharse) to be taken down by the young (y ng)
secretary , kept to a narrow path between
hedges. While ranged the (th) world, indulging (indulgn) all
curiosities (curisoities), mixing garrulously (garrul usly) with every one, Bacon kept
to the narrow path. Yet even in the shade his thought
is embodied. His deep meditations are given concrete form.
"Nay retire men cannot (acnnot) when they would: neither will they
when it were reason; but are impatient (impateint) of privateness
even in age and sickness which require the Shadow: Like old
Townmen that will be still sitting at their street door,
though thereby they offer Age to scorn." Even in the
thought is (ic) coloured. The Colours that show best
by candlelight , are: White, Carnation, and a kinde of
Sea-Water Green". It only needs the playwright to put one push for their thoughts
flesh and blood onto his thoughts. to become [people?]

Bacons contempt was for hyperbole; not for the art of
speech. He was teaching the ranting players to speak
slowly, closely, subtly. He was proving that there is another (anothe)
kind of poetry, the poetry of prose. He was bringing the
prose of the mind into being. And thus by increasing the
range of the poet, bu making it possible for him to express
more, he was making an end of anonymity.
